alert.note: Alert for Cherokee; York (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 2:51AM EST until January 11 at 4:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North and South Carolina... Broad River near Blacksburg affecting Cleveland County in North Carolina and Cherokee County in South Carolina. ...Observed flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in North Carolina... Broad River at Boiling Springs affecting Cleveland County. .The floodwave peak has passed through the Broad River in Cleveland and Cherokee counties. The Broad River near Boiling Springs crested at 15.28 feet at 06:30pm and near Blacksburg crested at 21.11 feet at 11:45pm on Tuesday. However, significant flows continue along the Broad River as the remainder of the floodwave passes through and the river remains in Minor to Moderate flood. Therefore, it will take at least another 18-24 hours for the Broad River to fall back below bankfull levels. The River Flood Warnings for Cleveland and Cherokee counties will continue until the river falls back below Action/Advisory Stage. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TONIGHT... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Broad River In SC near Blacksburg. * WHEN...Until late tonight. * IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, Minor Flooding continues. The Cherokee Falls Hydro Project operations may be impacted by excessively high flows. Floodwaters may be impacting access to the Cherokee Falls powerhouse and inundating residential yards adjacent to the river. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:15 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 20.8 feet and falling steadily. - Action/Advisory Stage is 13.0 feet. - The Broad River near Blacksburg crested at 21.11 feet at 11:45pm on Tuesday. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below Minor Flood Stage this evening and continue falling to 4.9 feet by early Monday morning. - Minor Flood Stage is 16.0 feet. Moderate Flood Stage is 22.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 21.1 feet on 03/20/2003. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued beforethis evening at 1100 PM EST.
